metadata.case_name: Brijendralal Gupta & Anr. v. Jwalaprasad & Ors.

facts.text: Polling took place on February 25, 1957, at the General Election to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from the Mamendragarh Double Member Constituency.

Thirteen candidates filed nominations: Appellants Brijendralal Gupta (general seat) and Thakur Raghubir Singh (reserved seat) for Congress; Respondents 1 and 7 for Praja Socialist Party; Respondents 4 and Sadhuram for Jan Sangh; others independent.
Udebhan Tiwari (respondent 5) omitted declaration of age in his nomination paper.
Scrutiny of nomination papers on February 1, 1957; returning officer rejected respondent 5's nomination due to omission of age, holding it a substantial defect necessary under Art. 173 Constitution.
Respondent 6 withdrew candidature; eleven candidates contested.
Appellants declared duly elected to general and reserved seats after counting.
Jwalaprasad (respondent 1) filed election petition under s.81 RPA 1951 challenging appellants' election, including ground of improper rejection of respondent 5's nomination.
Election Tribunal, Raigarh, in Election Petition No.76/1957, framed 49 issues; held rejection proper as substantial defect, no attempt to rectify, dismissed petition on May 12, 1959.

Respondent 1 appealed to Madhya Pradesh High Court, Jabalpur, in First Appeal No.78/1959; High Court allowed appeal on November 23, 1959, holding respondent 5 offered to supply age, RO bound to enquire, omission not substantial, set aside appellants' election under s.100(1)(c) RPA.
Appellants appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.
High Court finding that respondent 5 offered to rectify omission but RO refused accepted by Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Does the failure of a candidate to specify his age as required by the prescribed form of the nomination paper amount to a defect of a substantial character under s.36(4) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951?
Whether returning officer was required to hold summary enquiry under s.36(2) before rejecting nomination for omission of age.

petitioner_arguments.text: Omission to specify age constitutes failure to comply with s.33 RPA, attracting s.36(2)(b); it is a defect of substantial character under s.36(4), not clerical/technical; RO not required to enquire under s.36(2)(a).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33, s.36(2)(b), s.36(4) RPA 1951; Art.173 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Age declaration as important as name, signature; akin to attestation for illiterates or other substantial requirements.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rattan Anmol Singh v. Atma Ram; Pranlal Thakorlal Munshi v. Indubhai Bhailabhai Amin

respondent_arguments.text: Omission not substantial defect; RO should not reject on technical grounds, bound to hold summary enquiry under s.36(2)(a), check electoral roll (age 48 shown).
Courts should not adopt technical approach; substance over form.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Durga Shankar Mehta v. Thakur Raghuraj Singh; Pratap Singh v. Shri Krishna Gupta

court_reasoning.text: Omission to specify age is a defect under s.36(4); dictionary meaning includes lack of essential; unreasonable to exclude omissions from nomination form requirements.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defect includes omission to specify details prescribed in nomination paper.

court_reasoning.text: No enquiry under s.36(2)(a) required for non-compliance with s.33; falls under s.36(2)(b); reject if substantial defect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguish s.36(2)(a) (qualification enquiry where form compliant) from s.36(2)(b).

court_reasoning.text: Age as important as identity; declaration under form treated as candidate's own; prima facie eligibility under Art.173 crucial; not unsubstantial like symbols (deemed substantial by proviso to rule 5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to declare age on important matter is substantial defect.

court_reasoning.text: s.36(7) presumption limited to elector status (over 21, no disqualifications under s.16 RPA 1950); does not cover 25 years under Art.173; persons 21-25 electors but ineligible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Electoral roll does not prove 25+ age.

holdings.text: Omission to specify age in nomination paper is defect of substantial character under s.36(4) RPA 1951; rejection proper despite offer to rectify.
No summary enquiry required under s.36(2)(a) for s.33 non-compliance; only assess if substantial under s.36(2)(b)/(4).

precedents_cited.case_name: Rattan Anmol Singh v. Atma Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Failure to attest for illiterates is substantial defect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Durga Shankar Mehta v. Thakur Raghuraj Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Acceptance improper only if defect apparent on face or objection raised; no occasion to consider s.36(2)(b)/(4).

precedents_cited.case_name: Pranlal Thakorlal Munshi v. Indubhai Bhailabhai Amin
precedents_cited.relevance: Omission of age is substantial defect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pratap Singh v. Shri Krishna Gupta
precedents_cited.relevance: Substance over form, but for occupation omission not affecting merits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Karnail Singh v. Election Tribunal, Hissar
precedents_cited.relevance: Sub-division omission technical; unlike age declaration.
Omission of parish not cured as inaccurate description.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs nomination presentation, scrutiny, rejection for substantial defects, election petitions.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualifications for electoral roll; age 21+ for electors.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications for Legislative Assembly membership: 25+ years.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, upheld Tribunal's dismissal of election petition; held omission of age substantial defect, rejection proper.

key_quotes.text: Does the failure of a candidate to specify his age as required by the prescribed form of the nomination paper amount to a defect of a substantial character under s.36(4) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951?
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It would be unreasonable to hold that the word defect under s.36(4) excludes all cases of omission to specify the details prescribed by the statute in the nomination paper.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument omission not a defect.

key_quotes.text: There is little doubt that the age of the candidate is as important as his identity, and... failure to specify the age does not amount to a defect of a substantial character.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on substantiality of age omission.
